item.title: License modified to GNU LGPL version 3
item.text: The license agreement for this library has been changed to GNU LGPL, version 3. This change was made for compatibility reasons and most users will remain unaffected.

item.title: Added Visual Basic.NET code generation
item.text: A Visual Basic.NET source code generator has been contributed by Adrian Moore. It uses the same run-time library (DLL) as the C# .NET version.

item.title: Added support for case-insensitive parsing
item.text: A CASESENSITIVE grammar declaration has been added to make it possible to parse in case-insensitive mode. By default all parsing is case-sensitive. Thanks to Adrian Moore for providing a partial implementation.

item.title: Added support for reusing parsers and tokenizers
item.text: A reset() method has been added to both the Parser and the Tokenizer classes, allowing to reuse a parser with a new input stream. By reusing a single parser and tokenizer for various input files speed and memory gains can be made, especially for complex grammars.

item.title: Added factory methods for creating various objects
item.text: New factory methods for creating tokens, productions, tokenizers and analyzers have been added. These can be overridden in subclasses to provide more specific classes if desired.

item.title: Improved the tokenizer processing speed
item.text: The tokenizer speed has been improved by using a custom DFA implementation for regular expressions. The tokenization phase now runs some 20-30% faster in the general case. &

item.title: Changed to use native Java regular expressions
item.text: Since the built-in regular expression library is not used as frequently after the implementation of DFA regular expression handling, the native Java regular expression classes are now used. This implies improved support for advanced regular expression syntax (at a performance penalty). &

item.title: Changed .NET parser namespace for C# 2.0
item.text: The C# parser namespace has been modified from PerCederberg.Grammatica.Parser to PerCederberg.Grammatica.Runtime due to the new C# 2.0 compiler strictness.

item.title: Changed .NET parser API for better integration
item.text: The .NET parser API has been modified for almost all classes, introducing properties and indices instead of getter and setter methods. The old methods have been deprecated, but are still available to avoid breaking existing applications.

item.title: Changed built-in regular expression API subtly
item.text: Due to fixes required to be able to reuse tokenizers, the built-in regular expression class API had to be changed subtly. In essence, all the methods can now throw IOException which breaks a Java compile.

item.title: Fixed possible divide by zero in profiling
item.text: When profiling grammars with small input files, the time measured could previously be zero (0). This caused a division by zero exception when calculating the number of tokens parsed per second.

item.title: Fixed parse error on some grammar comments
item.text: Grammar comments ending with "**/" previously caused a parse error. The comment token regular expression has now been corrected to fix this.

item.title: Fixed premature EOF reported in some cases
item.text: The tokenizer previously assumed EOF had been encountered when a full look-ahead buffer couldn't be read. Thanks to Jeremy M Stone for finding this.

item.title: Fixed token match priority to use the grammar order
item.text: String tokens were previously always checked and considered first, unless a regular expression token matched more characters. This has now been changed to depend on the grammar file ordering instead.

item.title: Added Apache Ant task
item.text: An Apache Ant task has been added to the distribution. See the reference manual for details on how to use it.

item.title: Added support for retrieving all tokens
item.text: The Tokenizer class now supports enabling a useTokenList feature, that will link all tokens in a double-linked list. This can be used to access whitespace and comment tokens, although otherwise ignored by the parser. By default this feature is off, to avoid potetial garbage collection problems when parsing large files.

item.title: Removed API documentation for unsupported API
item.text: Java API documentation for the unsupported API:s in Grammatica is no longer created or distributed.

item.title: Corrected a null pointer error in --profile
item.text: When using --profile a null pointer exception was thrown during the parsing of the file. This was due to the analyzer being set to null, something that has now been made impossible.

item.title: Added C# API documentation
item.text: C# API documentation has now been added to the release documentation. The build file uses CppDoc to generate the HTML documents.

item.title: Added source code examples to documentation
item.text: Some examples of Java source code for creating a parser has been added to the reference manual.

item.title: Improved and clarified the Analyzer API
item.text: The Analyzer class API has been clarified by improving the generated comments slightly and by adding a getChildValues() method.

item.title: Corrected generation of C# analyzer classes
item.text: The generation of C# analyzer classes was completely broken in all previous releases, due to missing keywords and erroneous casing of method names. Tests have now been added to verify the generated analyzers. This was only an issue in the C# code generation, as the Java version has been tested continuously. &

item.title: Added profiling for grammars
item.text: A new action --profile has been added that prints out the statistics from a profiling run of the grammar. This is useful for improving the grammar and parsing speed.

item.title: Improved tokenizer performance
item.text: The tokenizer performance has been much improved for string tokens. The tokenization speed is now about twice as fast (on average), meaning that the tokenizer will use half as much time for most input and grammars.

item.title: Improved the parse tree output on error
item.text: The parse tree was previously only printed when a file could be parsed correctly. Now the parse tree is printed until the first syntax error is found.

item.title: Improved error message for missing '%' character
item.text: When missing the final '%' character in the grammar file, the error message printed was not logical. This has been improved by printing an 'unterminated directive' error instead.

item.title: Improved the reference manual
item.text: The reference manual has been improved to the point where it is considered finished. There is still room for much improvement, however, and such fixes will added in later versions.

item.title: Corrected unexpected token error messages
item.text: In some circumstances the unexpected token error messages didn't list all possible tokens. This only ocurred for productions containing alternatives with ambiguities that were resolved with one alternative being set as the default. This has now been corrected, which should also improve the error recovery in these cases.

item.title: Added automatic error recovery
item.text: Automatic error recovery is now always attempted without any changes to the grammar. Unfortunately the parser library API had to be changed a bit to make this possible.

item.title: Added debug printout of the interpreted grammar
item.text: A new action --debug has been added that prints out the internal representation of the grammar. This is useful for debugging, as it also prints the look-ahead token sets calculated.

item.title: Improved speed of the look-ahead calculation
item.text: Calculating look-ahead sequences longer than four (4) tokens, could be very slow in previous versions. This was due to the algorithm being used. A new algorithm has now been implemented, speeding up the process and allowing calculation of look-aheads of at least 10 tokens length.

item.title: Corrected stack overflow in regular expressions
item.text: Regular expressions containing reluctant quantifiers (such as '*?') caused stack overflow errors when matching long input strings (about 4096 characters). This has now been fixed in both the C# and Java versions, and new automatic test cases have been added.

item.title: Corrected failing regular expression match
item.text: Tokens with regular expression patterns sometimes didn't find a proper match. This only occured for expressions containing quantifiers ('*', '+', '*?' and '+?'), and only extremely seldom due to a failure to reset previous matches. This was only ever an issue in the Java version, where it has now been fixed.

item.title: Improved grammar error reporting
item.text: Error messages printed by Grammatica have been much improved in various ways. First, the exception traces are no longer printed by default. Secondly, the faulting line is printed on many errors (as done by javac). Thirdly, ambiguity errors are now reported with a list of conflicting tokens, making them easier to understand.

item.title: Corrected parse tree analyzer child handling
item.text: A bug in the base Analyzer class caused the child() methods not to be called when processing a parse tree after creation (both for C# & Java). When analyzing through callbacks things did work as expected, though.

item.title: Added creation of C# parsers (for .NET)
item.text: The parser runtime library has been ported to C#, so it is now possible to generate parsers for .NET languages. A C# parser output has also been added to the main program.

item.title: Added unit tests for generated parsers
item.text: Validation of the parsers generated for both C# and Java has been automated in unit tests. A bug in the previous release was detected through these tests (see below).

item.title: Added a first draft reference manual
item.text: A first short reference manual has been added to the documentation. The reference manual is generated to HTML from XML just as the release notes.

item.title: Corrected parse exception creation bug
item.text: When creating a parse exception, the LL(k) parser in some situations caused a NullPointerException. This has now been corrected.

item.title: Created XML generated documentation
item.text: The release documentation is now available in both text and HTML format. Both formats are generated with XSLT from a single source.

item.title: Added look-ahead loop detection
item.text: The look-ahead calculation now detects grammar loops and all grammar ambiguities. It should no longer be possible to cause infinite loops with a malformed grammar.

item.title: Added ambiguity resolution inside alternatives
item.text: Some ambiguities inside productions couldn't previously be resolved by the LL(k) parser. Productions like ["one"] "one" "two" contain an ambiguity between the first element and the second, but it is not inherent. This is now handled correctly by adding look-ahead sets for individual production elements.

item.title: Added expected tokens to parse errors
item.text: The parse error exceptions now contains a list of the expected tokens for the unexpected token errors.

item.title: Added automatic unit tests for the parser
item.text: A JUnit class testing the LL(k) parser has been added. These tests are executed upon every build to verify the integrity of the parser.

item.title: Addition of an internal regular expression library
item.text: This improves tokenizer performance by at least 100% compared to using the GNU RegExp library.

item.title: Addition of an analyzer framework with parser callbacks
item.text: A code generator has also been added to create default methods for all tokens and productions in the grammar.

item.title: Major refactorings of the tokenizer and parser classes
item.text: Various other classes have also been improved to simplify future feature additions.

item.title: Initial release
item.text: The first alpha release. This version was only available to a limited audience.
